title: 104th Division (Imperial Japanese Army)
text:
The was an <a href="infantry">infantry</a> <a href="Division%20%28military%20unit%29">division</a> of the <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Army">Imperial Japanese Army</a>. Its <a href="call%20sign">call sign</a> was the . It was formed 16 June 1938 in <a href="Osaka">Osaka</a> as a B-class <a href="square%20division">square division</a>. The nucleus for the formation was the <a href="4th%20Division%20%28Imperial%20Japanese%20Army%29">4th division</a> headquarters. The division was originally subordinated to the <a href="Japanese%20Northern%20China%20Area%20Army">Northern China Area Army</a>.
History.
Originally the "104th division" was sent for the escalating <a href="Battle%20of%20Lake%20Khasan">Battle of Lake Khasan</a> on Soviet border, but the battle was finished 11 August 1938. Therefore, the "104th division" was attached to <a href="Twenty-First%20Army%20%28Japan%29">21st Army</a> on 19 September 1938 and sailed from <a href="Dalian">Dalian</a> on 4 October 1938. It arrived in <a href="Daya%20Bay">Daya Bay</a> on 12 October 1938. The 137th Infantry Regiment then landed and proceeded inland to isolate <a href="Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a>, as part of the large-scale <a href="Canton%20Operation">Canton Operation</a>. Afterwards, the main garrison of the 104th Division was established in <a href="Conghua%20District">Conghua District</a>. On 9 February 1940 the <a href="Twenty-First%20Army%20%28Japan%29">21st Army</a> was dissolved and the 104th Division was reassigned to the <a href="Japanese%20Southern%20China%20Area%20Army">Southern China Area Army</a>.
The 104th Division was reassigned to the <a href="Twenty-Third%20Army%20%28Japan%29">23rd Army</a> in January 1941, and simultaneously lost the 170th Infantry Regiment, becoming a <a href="triangular%20division">triangular division</a>. The detached regiment was converted into the <a href="21st%20Independent%20Mixed%20Brigade%20%28Imperial%20Japanese%20Army%29">21st Independent Mixed Brigade</a> which was eventually sent to participate in the <a href="Japanese%20invasion%20of%20French%20Indochina%23Aftermath">Invasion of Southern French Indochina</a>.
After a long garrison service in <a href="Guangzhou">Guangzhou</a>, the 104th Division participated in <a href="Operation%20Ichi-Go">Operation Ichi-Go</a>, capturing <a href="Zhaoqing">Zhaoqing</a> on 16 September 1944, <a href="Wuxuan%20County">Wuxuan County</a> on 4 November 1944 and <a href="Xiangzhou%20County">Xiangzhou County</a> on 6 November 1944. Also, it captured <a href="Huizhou">Huizhou</a> on 15 January 1945 and <a href="Haifeng%20County">Haifeng County</a> on 18 January 1945. Until the <a href="surrender%20of%20Japan">surrender of Japan</a> on 15 August 1945, the 104th Division built coastal fortifications along the <a href="Daya%20Bay">Daya Bay</a> – <a href="Haifeng%20County">Haifeng County</a> – <a href="Lufeng%2C%20Guangdong">Lufeng</a> – <a href="Huizhou">Huizhou</a> line. The 161st Infantry Regiment and 104th Transport Regiment were concentrated at <a href="Daya%20Bay">Daya Bay</a>. The 108th Infantry Regiment was at <a href="Dongguan">Dongguan</a>. It was moved to the port of <a href="Taiping%2C%20Perak">Taiping, Perak</a> by 16 February 1946. The 137th Infantry Regiment was garrisoned at <a href="Haifeng%20County">Haifeng County</a>, and was moved to <a href="Humen%20Town">Humen Town</a> port on 19 February 1946. The 104th Artillery Regiment was located on the southern outskirts of <a href="Huizhou">Huizhou</a>, but was transferred on 18 February 1946 to <a href="Dongguan">Dongguan</a>. The 104th Engineer Regiment was in <a href="Huizhou">Huizhou</a>.
The division departed from <a href="Humen%20Town">Humen Town</a> port between 28 March and 2 April 1946, and arrived at <a href="Uraga%2C%20Kanagawa">Uraga, Kanagawa</a> between 6 and 19 April 1946. The dissolution of the 104th Division was complete by 23 May 1946.
